message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The correct answer is D, breath holding maneuver at functional residual capacity (FRC). This maneuver helps to recruit more alveoli and increase lung volume, leading to a decrease in PVR. Options A, B, and C do not have a significant effect on PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During a breath holding maneuver at FRC, there is no lung expansion or compression, which allows for maximum alveolar O2 and CO2 concentration. This causes pulmonary vasoconstriction, which can lead to a decrease in PVR. None of the other options cause this physiological response.

We refer to online resources on the physiology of the respiratory system for help. Pulmonary vascular resistance (PVR) is an index of the resistance of the pulmonary vascular bed. A breath holding maneuver at functional residual capacity (FRC) causes a decrease in intrathoracic pressure which in turn reduces resistance to venous return and decreases PVR. The other options do not have a direct effect on PVR.

We refer to basic physiology principles for help. PVR is determined by the diameter of the pulmonary arterioles. A breath holding maneuver at FRC causes increased intrathoracic pressure, which leads to decreased resistance in the pulmonary vasculature, allowing for increased blood flow and decreasing PVR. Inhaling IRV or VC and exhaling ERV do not have a direct effect on PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pulmonary vascular resistance is the resistance of the pulmonary vasculature to blood flow. Holding breath at functional residual capacity (FRC) decreases PVR as it decreases the amount of blood entering the pulmonary circulation, reducing resistance. None of the other options directly affect PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. When performing a breath holding maneuver at FRC, intrathoracic pressure increases, causing a decrease in PVR. Inhaling the IRV, exhaling the ERV, and inhaling the entire VC do not directly affect PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. PVR is decreased by decreasing alveolar oxygen tension, which can be achieved by a breath holding maneuver at functional residual capacity (FRC). Inhaling the IRV, exhaling the ERV, and inhaling the entire VC do not decrease PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A breath holding maneuver at FRC will increase intrathoracic pressure, leading to a decrease in PVR. Options A, B, and C do not have an effect on PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The answer is breath holding maneuver at functional residual capacity (FRC), which allows for increased alveolar oxygen pressure, resulting in vasodilation and decreased PVR. The other options do not directly affect PVR.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. During a breath holding maneuver at FRC, intrathoracic pressure increases, which leads to a decrease in pulmonary vascular resistance. Options A, B, and C do not cause changes in intrathoracic pressure and will not affect PVR.
